name: Photoacoustic Spectroscopy
summary: Photoacoustic spectroscopy (PAS) is a photothermal technique that detects absorbed light by measuring acoustic waves generated when modulated radiation heats a sample. Chopped or pulsed light (UV-Vis-NIR, 200-2500 nm typical) irradiates the sample; absorbed photons convert to heat via non-radiative relaxation; periodic heating causes thermal expansion generating pressure waves (ultrasound, 10 Hz - 10 MHz) detected by microphone or piezoelectric transducer. The photoacoustic signal amplitude versus wavelength yields an absorption spectrum revealing electronic and vibrational transitions. Unlike conventional transmission/reflectance spectroscopy, PAS directly measures absorption (not affected by scattering), penetrates opaque materials (depth-profiling via modulation frequency: 10 Hz → mm-scale, 10 kHz → μm-scale), and requires no sample preparation. Heritage applications include non-destructive pigment identification in paintings, subsurface layer detection through paint/varnish, photodegradation monitoring, and analysis of highly scattering materials (powders, textiles, paper) where conventional spectroscopy fails.
keyApplications: Pigment identification in opaque/scattering samples (powders, paints, no sample prep)
Subsurface layer detection (depth profiling: 1-1000 μm via frequency scanning)
Photodegradation monitoring (detect oxidation products, chromophore changes)
Highly scattering materials (textiles, paper, porous ceramics where reflectance spectroscopy ambiguous)
Non-contact analysis (standoff PAS: laser-induced, remote detection)
Binder characterization (organic overtone/combination bands in NIR)
destructiveness: non-destructive (typically; low power density avoids heating damage; <10 mW/cm²)
portability: benchtop to portable (lab systems 0.5×1 m; fiber-coupled portable PAS under development)
typicalTimePerMeasurement: 1-10 minutes per spectrum (200-2500 nm scan, 5 nm steps)

fundamentalPhysics.principle: Photoacoustic effect (Bell, 1880): modulated light absorbed by sample → periodic heating → thermal expansion/contraction → pressure waves (sound) in surrounding gas/coupling medium. Signal amplitude proportional to absorbed light intensity (not reflected/transmitted). Depth sensitivity controlled by thermal diffusion length μ_th = √(α/πf), where α = thermal diffusivity, f = modulation frequency. Low f (10-100 Hz) → large μ_th (mm-scale, bulk); high f (10-100 kHz) → small μ_th (μm-scale, surface-sensitive).
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: Light absorption → excited electronic/vibrational states → non-radiative relaxation (internal conversion, vibrational cascade) → heat deposited in sample → temperature oscillates at modulation frequency → thermal expansion generates pressure wave → acoustic wave propagates to detector (microphone in gas cell or piezo transducer on sample). Signal magnitude I_PA ∝ I₀ · β · μ_a, where I₀ = incident intensity, β = absorption coefficient, μ_a = thermal-to-acoustic conversion efficiency (depends on sample thermal properties, geometry). Unlike transmission (Beer's law, affected by scattering), PAS insensitive to scattering (scattered photons still eventually absorbed → heat → signal).

variables.meaning: modulation frequency (chopper or pulse repetition rate)
photoacoustic signal (microphone voltage or piezo charge)

equations.description: Typical Depth Scales (organic materials, α ~ 10⁻⁷ m²/s)

interactionDepth.description: Depth-resolved spectroscopy via frequency scanning. Low frequency (10-100 Hz) → thermal diffusion length 200-1000 μm (probes bulk, subsurface layers). High frequency (1-100 kHz) → 1-20 μm (surface-sensitive, top paint layer). Intermediate frequency → intermediate depths. Thermal wave attenuates exponentially: signal from depth z ∝ exp(-z/μ_th).

spatialResolution.lateral: Beam diameter: 1-10 mm typical (broader than focused techniques like Raman). Micro-PAS: 50-500 μm (focused laser, research systems).
spatialResolution.depth: Controlled by modulation frequency: 1 μm (100 kHz) to 1 mm (10 Hz). Depth profiling: scan frequency, extract spectra vs depth (deconvolution required).
limitingFactors: Thermal diffusion (not optical, so not diffraction-limited)
Sample thermal properties (α varies → depth varies)
Frequency range (detectors limit: microphones 10 Hz - 50 kHz; piezo 10 kHz - 10 MHz)

sensitivity.detectionLimits: Absorption coefficient β ~ 10⁻⁴ cm⁻¹ detectable (very weakly absorbing materials). Major component: 0.1-1 wt%. Trace: 100-1000 ppm with signal averaging.
sensitivity.dynamicRange: 10³-10⁴ in absorption (detect strong pigments to weak binder overtones in same spectrum).
sensitivity.signalToNoise: SNR 20-100:1 typical for strong absorbers (pigments). Averaging improves: 100× averages → 10× SNR improvement.

source.type: Broadband lamp (Xe arc, tungsten-halogen) + monochromator OR FTIR globar source. Laser-based PAS uses tunable laser or diode array.
source.specifications: Wavelength range: UV-Vis-NIR (200-2500 nm typical; extended to MIR 2.5-25 μm for FTIR-PAS). Power: 10-500 mW at sample (depends on wavelength, monochromator slit). Modulation: mechanical chopper (10-5000 Hz) or pulsed laser (kHz-MHz).
source.energyRange: 6 eV (200 nm UV) to 0.5 eV (2500 nm NIR). MIR: 0.5 eV to 0.05 eV (400-4000 cm⁻¹).
source.powerRange: Low power density: 1-100 mW/cm² (safe, non-destructive; vs. 1-10 W/cm² for Raman which can damage).

type: Microphone (gas-coupled PAS): electret or condenser microphone in sealed cell, detects acoustic pressure in air/He/N₂
Piezoelectric transducer (contact PAS): PZT or PVDF film attached to sample back, detects mechanical vibration
Fiber-optic acoustic sensor (remote PAS): interferometric, detects air pressure at distance
detector.spectralRange: Detection independent of wavelength (acoustic signal, not optical). Excitation range: UV-Vis-NIR 200-2500 nm or MIR 2.5-25 μm.
detector.efficiency: Microphone sensitivity: ~10 mV/Pa (detect Pa-level pressure waves). Piezo: pC/N (charge per force). Typical SNR 50:1 for strong absorbers.
detector.timeResolution: Frequency response: microphones 10 Hz - 50 kHz; piezo 10 kHz - 10 MHz. Temporal resolution limited by thermal diffusion time (~ms for μm-scale, ~s for mm-scale).

components: Light source (Xe lamp 200-800 nm, tungsten-halogen 400-2500 nm, or FTIR globar 2.5-25 μm)
Monochromator or FTIR spectrometer (wavelength selection: grating or interferometer)
Mechanical chopper (rotating blade, 10-5000 Hz modulation) or laser pulser
Photoacoustic cell (sealed chamber: sample + gas + microphone, or sample + piezo transducer)
Lock-in amplifier (phase-sensitive detection at chopper frequency, rejects noise)
opticalSystem.beamPath: Lamp → monochromator (selects λ) → chopper (modulates at f) → focusing optics → sample in PA cell → absorbed light → heat → acoustic wave → microphone/piezo → preamplifier → lock-in amplifier → digitize. Scan wavelength, record signal amplitude vs λ.
opticalSystem.focusing: Loose focusing or collimated beam (1-10 mm spot). Tight focusing (50-500 μm) for micro-PAS (research).

criticalComponents: Photoacoustic cell design (gas-tight for microphone; acoustic isolation from ambient noise; optimal geometry for signal coupling)
Lock-in amplifier (extracts weak signal at chopper frequency from noise; sensitivity ~nV, crucial for low-absorbing samples)
Chopper frequency control (determines depth; stable frequency ±1% for reproducible depth)
Sample mounting (intimate contact for piezo-PAS; flat surface for gas-cell PAS; powder samples loosely packed)
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: UV-Vis-NIR PAS: 150 W Xe arc lamp → Czerny-Turner monochromator (200-800 nm, 1200 l/mm grating) → mechanical chopper (20-200 Hz variable) → quartz window → gas-coupled PA cell (electret microphone, He atmosphere for better thermal coupling) → preamplifier → Stanford Research SR830 lock-in amplifier → PC. Scan 200-800 nm at 5 nm steps, 1 s integration per point (10 min total). Alternative FTIR-PAS: FTIR spectrometer (4000-400 cm⁻¹) with PAS accessory module (MTEC 300 or Bruker PAS cell), He-purged, rapid-scan FTIR modulation (~1 kHz effective).

facilityRequirements.space: Benchtop: 0.5 × 1 m (UV-Vis-NIR); 1 × 1.5 m (FTIR-PAS, larger spectrometer). Lab bench adequate.
utilities: Compressed gas (He or N₂, optional but improves signal; 10-50 psi, <1 L/min flow for cell purge)
environmental: Temp 18-25°C (thermal stability for PA cell, lock-in drift)
Acoustic isolation desirable (quiet room, reduces ambient noise pickup; <40 dB background preferred)
No special humidity control (sealed PA cell isolates sample from ambient)

commercialSystems.specifications: FTIR accessory, 4000-400 cm⁻¹ (MIR), He-purged, 8 mm sample diameter, electret microphone. Mounts in sample compartment of most FTIRs.
FTIR-PAS accessory, 4000-400 cm⁻¹, automated He purge, temperature control option. Compatible with Vertex series FTIRs.
200-2500 nm, variable chopper 10-5000 Hz, gas-cell or piezo, typical research lab builds. Commercial versions rare (niche market).
commercialSystems.approximateCost: $50,000-$150,000 (if commercial; many labs build custom systems $20-50K using lamp, monochromator, cell, lock-in)

samplePreparation.sampleSize: Micro-sample (mg-scale) or in situ (paintings, textiles analyzed directly). PA cell accommodates 5-20 mm diameter sample (disk, powder, or object surface if accessible).
samplePreparation.mountingProcedure: Gas-cell PAS: place sample flat in cell chamber (powder pressed lightly or loose; solid fragment on holder). Seal cell (O-ring, ensure gas-tight). Purge with He (5-10 min, displace air → improves thermal coupling). Piezo-PAS: attach transducer to sample back with couplant (ultrasound gel or pressure contact).
samplePreparation.surfacePreparation: None required (major advantage vs. FTIR-ATR which needs intimate contact). Rough, curved, powdered surfaces acceptable. Dust/contamination on surface contributes to signal (may need cleaning if surface layer not of interest).
contaminationConcerns: Surface contamination (dust, fingerprints) analyzed along with bulk if low-frequency (bulk-sensitive). High-frequency isolates surface, so contamination dominates.
Atmospheric moisture in cell (affects NIR overtone region 1300-1900 nm; He purge eliminates).

steps.title: System Setup and Calibration
steps.description: Turn on lamp (warm 15-30 min for spectral stability). Calibrate wavelength (use emission line standards: Hg, Ar lamps; verify monochromator at known lines ±1 nm). Set chopper frequency (20-200 Hz typical for paintings, 100-1000 Hz for surface-sensitive). Tune lock-in amplifier (time constant 100 ms - 1 s, phase adjustment for maximum signal on reference absorber like carbon black).
criticalParameters: Chopper frequency stable (±1%, determines depth consistently)
Lock-in phase optimized (90° out of phase with chopper gives max signal)

steps.title: Sample Loading and Cell Preparation
steps.description: Mount sample in PA cell (flat against window for gas-cell; powder lightly pressed). Seal cell, purge with He (5-10 min, flow rate 50-100 mL/min, vent to exhaust). Verify seal (acoustic isolation: tap table, if microphone signal spikes, seal poor). Adjust light focus (maximize illuminated area on sample, typically 5-10 mm spot).
criticalParameters: Gas-tight seal (prevents ambient noise, ensures stable gas atmosphere)
He purge complete (dry gas improves thermal coupling, removes H₂O vapor IR bands)

steps.title: Reference Spectrum Acquisition
steps.description: Acquire PA spectrum of reference absorber (carbon black powder, or instrument's internal reference). This normalizes lamp intensity, monochromator efficiency, detector response vs wavelength. Reference S_ref(λ) accounts for system spectral response (lamp + optics + detector). Sample spectrum S_sample(λ) divided by S_ref(λ) gives corrected absorption spectrum.
criticalParameters: Reference strongly absorbing (flat absorption spectrum ideal; carbon black approximates)
Stable reference (measure at start of session, verify at end; if drifted >5%, re-measure)

steps.title: Sample Spectrum Acquisition
steps.description: Scan wavelength (UV-Vis-NIR: 200-800 nm or 400-2500 nm, step size 5 nm typical). At each wavelength: lock-in integrates signal for t_int (0.3-3 s, longer for low-absorbing samples or better SNR). Record lock-in output (proportional to PA signal amplitude) vs wavelength. Monitor signal (software displays real-time spectrum, check for artifacts: sudden jumps indicate acoustic noise, drift indicates thermal instability).
steps.duration: 5-15 minutes (depending on wavelength range, steps, integration time)
criticalParameters: Wavelength step size (5 nm adequate for broad pigment bands; 1-2 nm for detailed structure)
Integration time (balance speed vs SNR; typically 1 s per point sufficient for pigments)
Signal stability (if noisy: reduce ambient acoustic noise, increase averaging, or lower chopper frequency)

steps.title: Depth Profiling (Optional)
steps.description: To probe different depths: repeat spectrum at multiple chopper frequencies (e.g., 20 Hz, 100 Hz, 500 Hz, 2000 Hz). Low frequency → deeper; high frequency → surface. Each frequency gives spectrum weighted toward corresponding depth. Deconvolution algorithms (inverse problem, thermal wave modeling) extract depth-resolved spectra. Requires expertise, specialized software. Simple approach: compare spectra at two frequencies (low = bulk + surface; high = surface only; subtract to estimate bulk contribution).
steps.duration: 30 minutes - 2 hours (4-10 frequencies × 10 min per spectrum)
criticalParameters: Frequency range (span 1-2 orders of magnitude; e.g., 20-2000 Hz covers ~10-100 μm depth range for organics)
Sample thermal properties (if α unknown, depth interpretation qualitative only)
Deconvolution validity (model assumes homogeneous layers, known α; complex structures harder to resolve)

steps.title: Data Processing and Quality Control
steps.description: Normalize sample spectrum: A_norm(λ) = S_sample(λ) / S_ref(λ). This corrected spectrum approximates absorption coefficient vs wavelength (proportional, not absolute unless calibrated with known absorber). Baseline correction if needed (PAS sometimes shows sloping baseline due to thermal effects; polynomial fit and subtract). Identify absorption features: peaks correspond to electronic transitions (pigments in UV-Vis) or overtone/combination bands (organics in NIR). Compare to reference spectra (databases, literature). Verify reproducibility: re-measure same sample (spectra should match ±5%); if not, check seal, He purge, sample position.
criticalParameters: Normalization accuracy (reference spectrum quality affects all samples; poor reference → systematic errors)
Baseline flat (if strongly curved, thermal artifacts present; check cell design, sample mounting)
Reproducibility (±5-10% typical; larger variation indicates unstable measurement conditions)

operatingParameters.notes: Low (10-100 Hz) = bulk (100-1000 μm depth). High (1-10 kHz) = surface (1-20 μm). Mid-range (100-500 Hz) = typical pigment layer (~50-200 μm).
Higher intensity → stronger signal but risk heating damage. Pigments tolerate 100 mW/cm²; organics/dyes <50 mW/cm².
Longer improves SNR (√t). Typical: 1 s adequate for pigments, 3-10 s for weak absorbers (binders, dilute dyes).
UV-Vis (200-800 nm): pigment electronic transitions. NIR (800-2500 nm): organic overtones (C-H, O-H). MIR (2.5-25 μm): fundamental vibrations (FTIR-PAS).
5 nm sufficient for broad pigment bands. 1-2 nm for detailed structure (sharp peaks, derivatives). 10-20 nm for rapid survey.
He preferred (high thermal conductivity, low heat capacity → stronger signal). Air acceptable but ~2-5× weaker. N₂ intermediate. Vacuum eliminates gas-coupling (use piezo instead).
Must fit PA cell. Larger samples need larger cell (custom). Smaller samples (1-5 mm) possible but require micro-PAS cell (research systems).

standards: Carbon black powder (broadband absorber, flat spectrum UV-Vis-NIR; used as reference to normalize system response)
Colored glass filters (Schott, Hoya): known absorption peaks, verify wavelength accuracy ±2 nm
Holmium oxide (Ho₂O₃) glass: sharp peaks at 241, 287, 361, 418, 453, 536, 640 nm (UV-Vis wavelength calibration)
Polystyrene film (NIR): C-H overtone bands 1680, 1728, 1760 nm (verify NIR calibration)
calibration.frequency: Daily: verify lamp output stable (measure reference carbon black, compare to previous day; intensity ±10%). Weekly: wavelength calibration (Ho₂O₃ or emission lines). Monthly: full system check (reference spectrum, detector noise, lock-in performance).
calibration.procedure: Wavelength calibration: place Ho₂O₃ glass in PA cell, acquire spectrum, identify peaks, compare to known positions (e.g., 536 nm peak). If shifted, adjust monochromator wavelength offset in software. System response: measure carbon black PA spectrum S_ref(λ), save as reference file (all sample spectra divided by this).

checkpoints: Reference spectrum smooth (no spikes, sudden jumps; if noisy, lamp unstable or acoustic interference)
Baseline approximately flat after normalization (if sloped, check reference quality, thermal artifacts)
Reproducibility: remeasure same sample, spectra match ±5-10%
Depth dependence logical: low frequency (bulk) includes all features; high frequency (surface) shows only surface-layer features; surface-only peaks should be absent or reduced in bulk spectrum
commonArtifacts: Acoustic noise spikes (external vibration, building HVAC, people walking): narrow peaks at random wavelengths, vary between scans. Mitigation: acoustic isolation (foam around PA cell), measure in quiet hours (night), or average multiple scans (noise random, averages out).

Thermal drift baseline (sample or cell heating over time → signal drift): sloping baseline, baseline shifts during scan. Cause: excessive light intensity, poor thermal contact, ambient temperature change. Mitigation: reduce intensity, ensure good sample-gas thermal coupling (He atmosphere, intimate contact), stabilize room temp.

Moisture bands (NIR 1400, 1900 nm broad peaks from H₂O vapor in cell): incompletely purged cell. Mitigation: longer He purge (10-15 min), higher flow rate, or measure in dry region only (400-1300 nm).

Saturation (very strong absorbers → signal plateau, loss of linearity): PA signal saturates if absorption too high (all light absorbed in <μ_th, no depth variation). Mitigation: dilute sample (mix with non-absorbing powder like BaSO₄), use thinner sample, or increase frequency (shallower probe → less total absorption).

Wavelength shift vs. reflectance spectrum (PAS peaks may shift 5-10 nm from literature reflectance spectra): PAS measures absorption directly; reflectance affected by scattering, Kubelka-Munk transformation approximates absorption. Small shifts normal, but large (>20 nm) indicates calibration error or wrong material.

troubleshooting.problem: No signal or very weak signal
troubleshooting.cause: Sample non-absorbing at measured wavelengths; poor gas-thermal coupling; microphone failed; lock-in phase wrong; light not reaching sample
troubleshooting.solution: Test with carbon black (should give strong signal across UV-Vis-NIR; if not, problem with system not sample). Check He purge (air in cell → weak signal, purge 10 min). Verify light path (observe sample under illumination, should see bright spot). Adjust lock-in phase (scan phase 0-360°, maximize signal). Check microphone connection (loose cable common failure).

troubleshooting.problem: Signal too strong (saturates lock-in or ADC)
troubleshooting.cause: Sample too strongly absorbing; light intensity too high; lock-in gain too high
troubleshooting.solution: Reduce light intensity (neutral density filter, or close monochromator slits). Increase chopper frequency (shallower probe → less total absorption). Decrease lock-in sensitivity (lower gain setting). If sample dilutable (powder), mix with BaSO₄ or other non-absorber.

troubleshooting.cause: Ambient acoustic noise; mechanical vibration; electronic interference (60 Hz hum); low sample absorption (weak signal)
troubleshooting.solution: Acoustic isolation (foam wrap cell, close doors, measure at night). Ground loops (check electrical grounds, use isolation transformer). Increase averaging (longer integration time, 3-10 s per point). Increase light intensity (if sample tolerates). Lower chopper frequency (deeper probe → more molecules → stronger signal, but less surface-sensitive).

troubleshooting.cause: Sample damage (photodegradation, thermal); ambient temperature drift; He purge inconsistent; sample movement
troubleshooting.solution: Reduce light intensity immediately (if photodamage suspected; organics, dyes especially sensitive). Stabilize room temperature (±1°C). Ensure consistent He purge (same flow, time for each sample). Secure sample (check mounting, vibration may shift position). If truly time-varying (e.g., photochromic material), measure quickly or in dark between scans.

troubleshooting.problem: Depth profiling shows unexpected trends (e.g., surface more absorbing than bulk, but expect opposite)
troubleshooting.cause: Deconvolution artifacts; incorrect thermal diffusivity assumption; sample not layered structure (gradual composition change vs. discrete layers)
troubleshooting.solution: Verify thermal properties (measure or estimate α more carefully; if uncertain, depth interpretation qualitative only). Check model assumptions (deconvolution assumes homogeneous layers with sharp interfaces; real samples may have gradients, voids, mixtures → complicates interpretation). Simplify analysis: qualitative comparison of low-freq (bulk-like) vs high-freq (surface-like) spectra, avoid quantitative depth extraction unless confident in model.

fileFormats: ASCII text (.txt, .csv): wavelength (nm) vs. lock-in output (V)
Vendor formats (if using FTIR-PAS: .spa, .spc from Bruker/Thermo; standard FTIR formats)
rawDataFormat.dataStructure: 1D spectrum: typically 100-500 data points (wavelength vs PA signal amplitude). Multi-frequency depth profiling: 2D (wavelength × frequency) or 3D (wavelength × depth after deconvolution).
rawDataFormat.typicalFileSize: 10-100 KB per spectrum (small; ASCII text). Multi-frequency set: 0.5-2 MB.

preprocessing.description: Divide sample spectrum by reference (carbon black or system response function): A_norm(λ) = S_sample(λ) / S_ref(λ). Corrects for lamp spectrum, monochromator efficiency, detector response. Essential step.

If normalized spectrum shows sloping baseline (thermal artifacts, incomplete normalization), fit polynomial (order 1-3) to baseline regions (wavelength ranges with no peaks), subtract from spectrum. Makes peaks easier to identify, quantify.
If noisy: apply Savitzky-Golay filter (window 5-15 points) or moving average. Trade-off: reduces noise but can broaden peaks. Use judiciously (only if SNR <10:1).
MIR data often in wavenumber (cm⁻¹). Convert: ν̃ (cm⁻¹) = 10⁷ / λ (nm). Or use as-is if spectrometer outputs wavenumber.
preprocessing.software: FTIR software (Bruker OPUS, Thermo OMNIC) handles automatically

preprocessing.description: First or second derivative enhances overlapping peaks, resolves shoulders. Useful for complex mixtures. Common in FTIR analysis.

steps.title: Visual Inspection
steps.description: Plot normalized spectrum. Identify major peaks, shoulders, overall shape. Note wavelength ranges of absorption (e.g., visible pigment peaks 400-700 nm, NIR organic overtones 1400-1800 nm). Check for artifacts (spikes, unusual baseline).

steps.title: Peak Identification
steps.description: List peak wavelengths (maxima). Compare to reference spectra: pigment databases (Kremer, Golden Paints spectra), literature (journal articles, books on pigment spectroscopy). Assign peaks to electronic/vibrational transitions (e.g., 490 nm = vermilion, 590 nm = minium, 1720 nm = C-H overtone in oil).

steps.title: Quantitative Analysis (optional)
steps.description: Peak area/intensity ratios for mixture quantification (semi-quantitative; need calibration with known mixtures for accuracy). Kubelka-Munk transformation (if comparing to reflectance data): K/S = (1-R)² / 2R, but PAS directly gives ~K (absorption), so transformation less critical.

steps.title: Depth Profiling Analysis
steps.description: If multi-frequency data: plot spectra at each frequency. Identify features unique to surface (high-freq spectrum) vs bulk (low-freq). Deconvolution (advanced): use thermal wave model + inverse problem algorithms (Fourier deconvolution, least-squares fitting) to extract depth-resolved spectra. Requires expertise, software (MATLAB custom scripts, or specialized PAS software like WinPAS).

steps.title: Comparison to Other Techniques
steps.description: Correlate PAS spectrum with XRF (elemental composition), Raman (molecular structure), FTIR (if both available). PAS absorption spectrum should match material ID from other techniques (e.g., PAS shows vermilion absorption peak, XRF shows Hg, Raman shows HgS 254 cm⁻¹ → consistent).

softwareTools.name: OriginLab
capabilities: Spectral plotting, baseline correction, peak fitting, simple processing

softwareTools.name: MATLAB / Python
capabilities: Custom processing, deconvolution algorithms, multivariate analysis, automation

softwareTools.name: OPUS (Bruker) / OMNIC (Thermo)
capabilities: FTIR-PAS data acquisition, processing, library search (MIR region)

softwareTools.name: WinPAS
capabilities: PAS-specific analysis, depth deconvolution, thermal modeling

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: PAS spectrum = absorption spectrum (direct, not affected by scattering). UV-Vis region (200-800 nm): electronic transitions (pigments, dyes, chromophores). NIR (800-2500 nm): overtone/combination bands (C-H, O-H, N-H in binders, organics; weaker than fundamentals, ~10-100× less intense). MIR (2.5-25 μm, FTIR-PAS): fundamental vibrations (strong, characteristic; similar to FTIR transmission but no sample prep). Peak positions match literature ±5-10 nm (PAS sometimes shifts slightly vs reflectance due to different measurement geometry, but close). Depth profiling: compare low-freq (bulk) vs high-freq (surface); surface peaks present in high-freq but absent/reduced in low-freq indicate surface layer (e.g., varnish 1720 nm C-H over paint). Artifacts: moisture bands (1400, 1900 nm), acoustic noise (random spikes), thermal drift (sloping baseline).

primaryUseCases: Pigment ID in powders, paints (no sample prep; scattering-insensitive unlike reflectance)
Subsurface layer detection (varnish over paint, underdrawing under paint via depth profiling)
Photodegradation studies (monitor chromophore changes, oxidation products over time/light exposure)
Textiles, paper (highly scattering; PAS works where reflectance/transmission fail)
Binder characterization (NIR overtones: oil 1720 nm, protein 1500-1680 nm broad, polysaccharide 1400-1500 nm)
Non-contact analysis (laser-PAS: remote detection for delicate/large objects)

materialTypes.notes: Ideal: PAS insensitive to powder particle size, packing density (unlike diffuse reflectance). Direct absorption spectrum.
Surface analysis possible (fiber-coupled system or portable PAS under development). Depth profiling reveals varnish/paint/ground layers.
Highly scattering materials; PAS superior to reflectance (scattering doesn't affect PAS signal). Dye ID, fiber characterization.
Transmission spectroscopy impossible (opaque). Reflectance weak (dark). PAS detects absorption directly regardless of darkness.
NIR overtones detectable (C-H 1700-1800 nm, O-H 1400-1500 nm). Weaker than pigments, but PAS sensitivity adequate. FTIR-PAS (MIR) better for fundamentals.
Raman fails (fluorescence overwhelms). PAS unaffected (non-radiative relaxation → heat regardless of fluorescence). Advantage over optical techniques.

caseStudies.title: Subsurface Pigment Detection in Murals: PAS Depth Profiling Reveals Overpaint Layers
caseStudies.institution: Getty Conservation Institute / University of Athens
caseStudies.objectType: Byzantine wall paintings (frescoes) with suspected later overpaint
caseStudies.researchQuestion: Are there original pigment layers under visible overpaint? Non-destructive depth profiling to guide selective cleaning.
caseStudies.methodology: Portable UV-Vis-NIR PAS system (Xe lamp, fiber-coupled to painting surface via contact PA cell, piezoelectric transducer). Measured 10 locations (overpainted areas + original areas for comparison). Frequency range: 20 Hz (bulk, ~500 μm depth), 50 Hz, 100 Hz, 500 Hz, 2 kHz (surface, ~10 μm). Acquisition: 400-800 nm, 5 nm steps, 2 s integration per wavelength. Normalized to carbon black reference. Analysis: compare spectra at different frequencies; identify pigments via peak positions.
caseStudies.keyFindings: Low-frequency spectra (20-100 Hz, probing 100-500 μm) showed ultramarine absorption (590 nm peak) + red ochre (broad 400-600 nm) at 8 locations, despite surface appearing light gray. High-frequency spectra (500-2000 Hz, surface 5-20 μm) showed only calcite/lime white (no distinct absorption peaks, flat 400-800 nm) + trace charcoal black (broad absorption). Interpretation: original fresco underneath (ultramarine + ochre) covered by later lime whitewash (calcite overpaint, 20-100 μm thick estimated from frequency dependence). Comparison to 2 visually 'original' areas (no suspected overpaint): all frequencies showed ultramarine + ochre (surface and bulk same → no overpaint). Depth profiling quantitative via thermal diffusion modeling: estimated overpaint thickness 40-80 μm (thermal diffusivity of lime mortar α ~ 6×10⁻⁷ m²/s; at 100 Hz, μ_th ~ 140 μm, signal attenuates from overpaint and underlying original; at 500 Hz, μ_th ~ 60 μm, mostly overpaint; fitting signal ratio 500 Hz / 100 Hz to two-layer model gives overpaint thickness). Conservation decision: mechanically removed overpaint (40-80 μm depth) in test areas, exposed ultramarine/ochre original as predicted. Guided full cleaning (PAS mapped extent of overpaint, prioritized areas, avoided original). Non-destructive preview crucial (prevented unnecessary damage to original areas, targeted intervention).
caseStudies.significance: Depth profiling demonstrated: PAS penetrates opaque overpaint (lime, calcite are weakly absorbing 400-800 nm, some light reaches original layer underneath; original pigments strongly absorbing, contribute to low-freq signal). Conventional reflectance spectroscopy sees only surface (overpaint, misses underlying). Raman struggles (lime fluorescence, pigment grains deep). XRF elemental (shows Ca surface + Cu/Fe underneath from azurite/ochre, but ambiguous: could be inhomogeneous single layer). PAS depth-resolved absorption = functional stratigraphy. Portable application: in-situ on vertical mural surface (no sampling, 10 min per location, non-contact piezo transducer). Limitations noted: depth resolution ~50 μm (cannot resolve very thin layers <20 μm); requires known thermal properties for quantitative depth (estimated here, ±30% uncertainty); complex layer stacks (>2 layers) harder to deconvolve unambiguously.

reference.citation: Romani, A., et al. 2015. 'Depth Profiling of Wall Paintings by Photoacoustic Spectroscopy.' J. Cultural Heritage 16: 54-60.

complementaryTechniques.rationale: XRF elemental, PAS molecular absorption. XRF identifies elements (Pb, Hg, Fe) → suggests pigments. PAS confirms via absorption spectrum (lead white vs minium both Pb, but different spectra). Depth: XRF ~10-100 μm fixed, PAS tunable 1-1000 μm.

Raman molecular structure (vibrational), PAS electronic/vibrational (UV-Vis-NIR). Complementary: Raman inorganics excellent, organics often fluoresce. PAS works on fluorescent materials (Raman fails). Depth: Raman surface ~μm, PAS tunable.

FTIR fundamental vibrations (MIR), PAS overtones/combinations (NIR). FTIR-PAS (MIR) = FTIR without sample prep (powders, rough surfaces). PAS-NIR = overtones (weaker but bulk-sensitive, depth profiling). Use together: MIR for strong binder peaks, NIR for depth.

Reflectance UV-Vis vs PAS UV-Vis: both probe electronic transitions. Reflectance affected by scattering (Kubelka-Munk approximation, indirect absorption). PAS direct absorption (scattering-insensitive). PAS superior for powders, dark/opaque materials. Reflectance easier (no special cell).

standardCombinations.name: PAS + XRF (Molecular + Elemental Depth Profiling)
standardCombinations.workflow: 1. XRF scan painting area (elemental map, identify pigment-rich regions, Pb/Hg/Cu hot spots). 2. PAS analyze selected locations: low-freq (bulk, ~500 μm) + high-freq (surface, ~10 μm) spectra. 3. Correlate: XRF elements + PAS absorption peaks → definitive pigment ID. 4. Depth compare: XRF fixed depth (~50 μm), PAS variable (tune frequency) → resolve discrepancies (e.g., XRF shows Pb surface + Fe underneath, PAS low-freq shows lead white + ochre, high-freq shows lead white only → confirms stratification).
standardCombinations.rationale: XRF fast spatial survey (seconds per point, map large areas). PAS slower (minutes per location) but depth-tunable, molecular ID. XRF guides PAS sampling (where to measure). PAS resolves XRF ambiguities (multiple Pb pigments, PAS spectra distinguish).
standardCombinations.exampleApplication: Painting with suspected underdrawing. XRF shows C (carbon) in underpaint region + Pb (lead white) overpaint. PAS low-freq (200 Hz, ~300 μm depth) shows broad carbon absorption (UV-Vis flat, no peaks, consistent with charcoal) + lead white absorption shoulder. PAS high-freq (2 kHz, ~20 μm, surface layer only) shows lead white dominant, carbon weak. Confirms carbon underdrawing beneath lead white paint (~50-200 μm deep estimated from frequency dependence).

advantages: Scattering-insensitive (direct absorption measurement; powders, rough surfaces, turbid media analyzed without correction)
No sample preparation (powders, fragments analyzed as-is; no pellets, polishing, coatings)
Depth profiling (tune modulation frequency: 1 μm surface to 1 mm bulk; non-destructive subsurface analysis)
Opaque materials compatible (dark, highly absorbing samples; transmission impossible, PAS works)
Fluorescence-insensitive (non-radiative relaxation → heat; fluorescence doesn't interfere unlike Raman)
Small sample volume (mg-scale adequate; non-destructive for valuable objects)
Wide spectral range (UV to MIR possible with appropriate sources: 200 nm - 25 μm)
limitations: Requires specialized equipment (PA cell, lock-in amplifier; less common than reflectance spectrophotometers; commercial systems limited)
Slower than reflectance (minutes per spectrum vs seconds; modulation + lock-in integration takes time)
Depth resolution limited (thermal diffusion ~5-500 μm typical; cannot resolve nm-scale layers like XPS)
Quantification complex (signal depends on absorption + thermal properties; semi-quantitative without calibration)
Thermal property dependence (depth interpretation requires knowing α; if unknown, qualitative only)
Acoustic noise susceptible (ambient vibration, HVAC, people → noise; requires quiet environment or isolation)
Surface contact needed for some modes (gas-cell PAS needs sample in cell; piezo-PAS needs transducer contact; limits in-situ on some objects)
advantagesLimitations.whenToUse: PAS ideal when: (1) highly scattering materials (powders, textiles, paper, porous; reflectance fails), (2) opaque/dark samples (transmission impossible, reflectance weak), (3) depth profiling needed (subsurface layers, underdrawing, overpaint), (4) fluorescent materials (Raman fails, PAS unaffected), (5) no sample prep possible (valuable micro-samples, irregular shapes), (6) direct absorption spectrum desired (not reflection-based approximation).
advantagesLimitations.whenNotToUse: Avoid PAS when: (1) rapid analysis needed (reflectance faster; PAS 5-15 min per spectrum), (2) high spatial resolution required (<1 mm; PAS spot size 1-10 mm typical; Raman/FTIR-micro better for μm-scale), (3) quantitative absorption coefficient needed (PAS semi-quantitative; UV-Vis transmission spectroscopy with known path length better), (4) sample inaccessible to PA cell (large objects, cannot contact; use remote reflectance instead, or develop laser-PAS if feasible), (5) very thin surface layers only (<1 μm; PAS minimum depth ~1-5 μm even at high frequency; use XPS, SIMS for nm-scale surface).

timeline.event: Alexander Graham Bell discovers photoacoustic effect (light → sound in materials)
timeline.significance: Foundational physics; demonstrated acoustic signal from modulated light absorption

timeline.event: Viengerov develops first gas-phase PAS for trace gas detection
timeline.significance: Analytical application; infrared PAS for CO₂, H₂O monitoring

timeline.event: Rosencwaig & Gersho develop theory for condensed-phase PAS; commercial FTIR-PAS accessories
timeline.significance: Modern PAS spectroscopy emerges; thermal diffusion model, depth profiling concepts established

timeline.event: Heritage applications begin: pigment analysis (powders), paper/textiles (scattering materials)
timeline.significance: PAS introduced to conservation science; advantages for opaque/scattering samples recognized

timeline.event: Portable PAS development (fiber-coupled, laser-based); depth profiling for paintings
timeline.significance: In-situ capability; subsurface layer detection in artworks without sampling

timeline.event: Integration with other techniques (PAS + XRF, PAS + Raman); advanced depth deconvolution algorithms
timeline.significance: Multi-modal workflows; computational methods improve depth resolution, quantification

firstHeritageApplication.reference: Systematic heritage use began 1980s: pigment powder analysis (direct absorption, no Kubelka-Munk needed), paper/textile dye characterization (scattering-free spectra). Recognized advantages for opaque, scattering materials common in cultural heritage.

historicalDevelopment.currentStateOfArt: PAS established niche technique in heritage science: FTIR-PAS accessories available (Bruker, MTEC; $15-40K add-on to FTIR for powders, fibers, rough samples). UV-Vis-NIR PAS mostly custom-built (research labs; few commercial portable systems). Depth profiling demonstrated (paintings, murals; frequency-scanned 10 Hz - 10 kHz resolves 10-1000 μm). Limitations: slower than reflectance, requires expertise, less widespread than Raman/FTIR (fewer labs have equipment). Future: portable laser-PAS (remote, non-contact), AI-driven depth deconvolution, integration with hyperspectral imaging.

costAnalysis.capitalEquipment: $30,000-$150,000. FTIR-PAS accessory: $15-40K (adds to existing FTIR, MIR range). Custom UV-Vis-NIR PAS: $50-150K (lamp, monochromator, chopper, PA cell, lock-in, software; or purchase components ~$20-50K, self-assemble).
costAnalysis.annualMaintenance: $2,000-$8,000. Lamp replacement (Xe arc ~$500-2000, every 1-2 years). Lock-in amplifier maintenance (minimal, robust). Microphone replacement ($100-500, if damaged). Calibration standards ($200/year). Service contract if commercial system ($3-8K/year).
costAnalysis.consumables: $200-$500/year. He gas (if purging: $100-300/year for 10-50 L/month). Sample holders, O-rings, seals ($100/year). Carbon black reference powder ($50).
costAnalysis.perSampleCost: $50-$200. Staff time: 1-3 hours (setup 30 min, measurement 10-30 min, processing 30-60 min) @ $50-100/hr. Consumables: negligible ($1-5 He gas per sample). Equipment use: amortized ~$20-50/session.

hazards: Light intensity (10-100 mW/cm², ~1/10 sunlight; safe, but prolonged exposure can heat sample slightly; risk of photodegradation for highly photosensitive materials like fugitive dyes)
Compressed gas (He cylinder: asphyxiation in confined space, high pressure; standard gas handling safety)
Electrical (110/240 VAC, standard lab safety; lamp high voltage during replacement)
safetyEquipment: Safety glasses (UV light if measuring <400 nm; block UV)
Gloves (handling samples with toxic pigments: Pb, Hg, As)
regulatoryCompliance: No special regulations (non-ionizing light, low power). Standard lab electrical safety (grounded equipment). Gas cylinder safety (secure, ventilated area).

emergingDevelopments: Portable laser-PAS (compact laser diode array, MEMS microphone, battery-powered → handheld system for field/gallery use)
Remote sensing PAS (laser excitation, fiber-optic or interferometric acoustic detection at distance → standoff analysis, no contact needed)
Hyperspectral PAS imaging (scan XY + wavelength → chemical maps with depth profiling; combine with imaging spectrometer)
Time-domain PAS (pulsed laser, measure acoustic transient → depth profiling via time-of-flight, higher depth resolution than frequency domain)
Machine learning depth deconvolution (neural network trained on multilayer PAS data → automatic layer extraction, composition vs depth)
aiMlIntegration: Automated pigment ID (neural network trained on PAS spectra database → classify pigment from spectrum, >95% accuracy for common pigments)
Depth profile inversion (ML inverts multi-frequency PAS data → depth-resolved absorption coefficient, avoids iterative thermal modeling)
Artifact detection (autoencoder flags anomalous spectra: acoustic noise, saturation, degradation → quality control)
